articles.headline: Facing a Dire Storm Forecast in Florida, Officials Delayed Evacuation
articles.snippet: A day of hesitation in Lee County came despite warnings that the Fort Myers and Cape Coral area could see mass flooding. Now authorities are encountering mass death.
articles.abstract: A day of hesitation in Lee County came despite warnings that the Fort Myers and Cape Coral area could see mass flooding. Now authorities are encountering mass death.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT MYERS, Fla. — As Hurricane Ian charged toward the western coast of Florida this week, the warnings from forecasters were growing more urgent. Life-threatening storm surge threatened to deluge the region from Tampa all the way to Fort Myers.
articles.byline: By Frances Robles, Mike Baker, Serge F. Kovaleski and Lazaro Gamio

articles.headline: British Ruling Pins Blame on Social Media for Teenager’s Suicide
articles.snippet: The internet, according to the ruling, “affected her mental health in a negative way and contributed to her death in a more than minimal way.”
articles.abstract: The internet, according to the ruling, “affected her mental health in a negative way and contributed to her death in a more than minimal way.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Sitting in the witness box of a small London courtroom this week, a Meta executive faced an uncomfortable question: Did her company contribute to the suicide of a 14-year-old named Molly Russell?
articles.byline: By Adam Satariano

articles.headline: In Washington, Putin’s Nuclear Threats Stir Growing Alarm
articles.snippet: In a gathering Cold War atmosphere, American officials are gaming out responses should Russia resort to battlefield nuclear weapons.
articles.abstract: In a gathering Cold War atmosphere, American officials are gaming out responses should Russia resort to battlefield nuclear weapons.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For the first time since the Cuban Missile Crisis in October 1962, top government leaders in Moscow are making explicit nuclear threats and officials in Washington are gaming out scenarios should President Vladimir V. Putin decide to use a tactical nuclear weapon to make up for the failings of Russian troops in Ukraine.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Anton Troianovski and Julian E. Barnes

articles.headline: Lawmakers Confront a Rise in Threats and Intimidation, and Fear Worse
articles.snippet: Violent political speech has increasingly crossed into the realm of in-person confrontation for members of Congress in both parties, raising the prospect of a disastrous event.
articles.abstract: Violent political speech has increasingly crossed into the realm of in-person confrontation for members of Congress in both parties, raising the prospect of a disastrous event.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In Bangor, Maine, an unknown visitor smashed a storm window at Senator Susan Collins’s home.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Lai, Luke Broadwater and Carl Hulse

articles.headline: American Prisoners Are Released From Venezuela and Iran
articles.snippet: Caracas freed seven Americans in a trade for two nephews of Venezuela’s first lady who had been convicted on drug charges. Separately, Tehran released its longest-held American captive.
articles.abstract: Caracas freed seven Americans in a trade for two nephews of Venezuela’s first lady who had been convicted on drug charges. Separately, Tehran released its longest-held American captive.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Seven Americans who had been held captive in Venezuela for years were on their way home Saturday after President Biden agreed to grant clemency to two nephews of Cilia Flores, Venezuela’s first lady, officials said. The men had been sentenced in 2017 to 18 years in prison for conspiring to smuggle cocaine into the United States.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Farnaz Fassihi

articles.headline: Ukraine Forces Retake Lyman, a Strategic City, as Russians Retreat
articles.snippet: Russia’s withdrawal from the city comes one day after Moscow illegally annexed the surrounding region.
articles.abstract: Russia’s withdrawal from the city comes one day after Moscow illegally annexed the surrounding region.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIVNE, Ukraine — Russian forces retreated from the strategic eastern Ukrainian city of Lyman on Saturday, a humbling setback for President Vladimir V. Putin just one day after he illegally declared the surrounding region to be part of Russia.
articles.byline: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Andrew E. Kramer, Anton Troianovski and Catherine Porter

articles.headline: The Racial Divide Herschel Walker Couldn’t Outrun
articles.snippet: As a teenage football prodigy, Mr. Walker was pressed to join a fight for civil rights in his hometown. His decision echoes decades later.
articles.abstract: As a teenage football prodigy, Mr. Walker was pressed to join a fight for civil rights in his hometown. His decision echoes decades later.
articles.lead_paragraph: WRIGHTSVILLE, Ga. — The race for a critical Senate seat was in full motion by midsummer, but there were just a few Herschel Walker campaign signs sprinkled around his hometown.
articles.byline: By John Branch

articles.headline: Mystery Solved: ‘Dateline’ Finds Path From TV to Podcast Stardom
articles.snippet: The true crime storytelling that has done so well for so long on television seems to have met a moment in an entirely new medium.
articles.abstract: The true crime storytelling that has done so well for so long on television seems to have met a moment in an entirely new medium.
articles.lead_paragraph: The podcast begins with the sound of a car slowing down, and then a straight-talking narrator takes over. “It was dark when the killer shut off the engine,” he says.
articles.byline: By John Koblin

articles.headline: A New Refrain From Artists: We ‘Almost Gave Up on Instagram’
articles.snippet: Photographers and illustrators who once eagerly shared images of their work on Instagram are moving away from the site as it emphasizes video.
articles.abstract: Photographers and illustrators who once eagerly shared images of their work on Instagram are moving away from the site as it emphasizes video.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Deb JJ Lee built a career in illustration on Instagram, one colorful comic at a time.
articles.byline: By Kalley Huang

articles.headline: ‘I Did All I Could’: As Floodwaters Rose, She Fought to Save Her Disabled Brothers
articles.snippet: Darcy Bishop for decades has cared for her two brothers, who have cerebral palsy. Hurricane Ian was her biggest test yet.
articles.abstract: Darcy Bishop for decades has cared for her two brothers, who have cerebral palsy. Hurricane Ian was her biggest test yet.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the water slipped in, it was just a glimmer on the floor, a sign that it was time to go.
articles.byline: By Corina Knoll

articles.headline: As New Term Starts, Supreme Court Is Poised to Resume Rightward Push
articles.snippet: The justices return to the bench on Monday to start a term that will include major cases on affirmative action, voting and discrimination against gay couples. Several will take on questions about race.
articles.abstract: The justices return to the bench on Monday to start a term that will include major cases on affirmative action, voting and discrimination against gay couples. Several will take on questions about race.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the Supreme Court hearings on affirmative action.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak

articles.headline: Fans Focus on Police After More Than 100 Die at Indonesian Soccer Match
articles.snippet: Witnesses said officers fired tear gas indiscriminately into the stands, causing a stampede that led to at least 125 deaths.
articles.abstract: Witnesses said officers fired tear gas indiscriminately into the stands, causing a stampede that led to at least 125 deaths.
articles.lead_paragraph: MALANG, Indonesia — It was supposed to be a joyous occasion for fans of Arema F.C., the most beloved soccer team in the city of Malang, Indonesia.
articles.byline: By Muktita Suhartono, Sui-Lee Wee and Dera Menra Sijabat

articles.headline: The Story Behind DeSantis’s Migrant Flights to Martha’s Vineyard
articles.snippet: Asylum seekers in Texas were recruited for the flights by a woman who appeared to be a former Army counterintelligence agent. “We were tricked,” one migrant said.
articles.abstract: Asylum seekers in Texas were recruited for the flights by a woman who appeared to be a former Army counterintelligence agent. “We were tricked,” one migrant said.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — In June, Gov. Ron DeSantis signed a budget that set aside $12 million to create a program for transporting unauthorized migrants out of Florida. He touted it as the highlight of the state’s new spending when it came to immigration.
articles.byline: By Edgar Sandoval, Miriam Jordan, Patricia Mazzei and J. David Goodman

articles.headline: I Lived in Russia? Annexation Is News to Key City Reclaimed by Ukraine.
articles.snippet: Without access to electricity, radios or the internet, residents of Lyman said they were unaware of President Vladimir V. Putin’s grandiose celebration of an illegal land grab.
articles.abstract: Without access to electricity, radios or the internet, residents of Lyman said they were unaware of President Vladimir V. Putin’s grandiose celebration of an illegal land grab.
articles.lead_paragraph: LYMAN, Ukraine — As dusk gathered on Sunday, Elena Kharkovska stood in the courtyard of her apartment block, contemplating what she had just learned: Without ever moving, she had supposedly lived in Russia for one day.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer and Nicole Tung

articles.headline: These Job-Training Programs Work, and May Show Others the Way
articles.snippet: A handful of innovators have developed successful programs to help lift low-income workers into the middle class. Can their model become the norm?
articles.abstract: A handful of innovators have developed successful programs to help lift low-income workers into the middle class. Can their model become the norm?
articles.lead_paragraph: For Amber Mitchell Ikpe, learning computer software skills was only part of the experience at Year Up, a nonprofit job training program.
articles.byline: By Steve Lohr

articles.headline: They Legitimized the Myth of a Stolen Election — and Reaped the Rewards
articles.snippet: On the day the Capitol was attacked, 139 Republicans in the House voted to dispute the Electoral College count. This is how they got there.
articles.abstract: On the day the Capitol was attacked, 139 Republicans in the House voted to dispute the Electoral College count. This is how they got there.
articles.lead_paragraph: Five days after the attack on the Capitol last year, the Republican members of the House of Representatives braced for a backlash.
articles.byline: By Steve Eder, David D. Kirkpatrick and Mike McIntire

articles.headline: How a Tiny Elections Company Became a Conspiracy Theory Target
articles.snippet: Election deniers catapulted a Michigan firm with just 21 U.S. employees to the center of unfounded voter fraud claims, exposing it to vicious threats.
articles.abstract: Election deniers catapulted a Michigan firm with just 21 U.S. employees to the center of unfounded voter fraud claims, exposing it to vicious threats.
articles.lead_paragraph: Editors’ Note, Oct. 6: After this article was published, the chief executive of Konnech, Eugene Yu, was arrested in connection with an investigation into the possible theft of personal information about poll workers. In communications with The Times for this article, neither Mr. Yu nor a spokesman for Konnech said that the company was the subject of an investigation. They also asserted that all the company’s data was stored on servers in the United States; prosecutors in Los Angeles, who brought the charges against Mr. Yu, said that they had found some company data stored on servers in China. The Times is continuing to report on this story.
articles.byline: By Stuart A. Thompson

articles.headline: A 95-Square-Foot Tokyo Apartment: ‘I Wouldn’t Live Anywhere Else’
articles.snippet: Meet the young Japanese who have decided to live in a shoe box.
articles.abstract: Meet the young Japanese who have decided to live in a shoe box.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — At the end of a long day at work in the offices of Japan’s professional baseball league, Asumi Fujiwara returned to her apartment and changed into pajamas. She wanted to get in a light workout before going to bed, so she placed her vinyl yoga mat on the floor in front of the toilet, rolling it past the single kitchen burner and the one-slot toaster and toward the foot of her desk.
articles.byline: By Hikari Hida

articles.headline: Less Turnover, Smaller Raises: Hot Job Market May Be Losing Its Sizzle
articles.snippet: Unemployment is low, and hiring is strong. But there are signs that frenzied turnover and rapid wage growth are abating.
articles.abstract: Unemployment is low, and hiring is strong. But there are signs that frenzied turnover and rapid wage growth are abating.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last year, Klaussner Home Furnishings was so desperate for workers that it began renting billboards near its headquarters in Asheboro, N.C., to advertise job openings. The steep competition for labor drove wages for employees on the furniture maker’s production floor up 12 to 20 percent. The company began offering $1,000 signing bonuses to sweeten the deal.
articles.byline: By Sydney Ember and Ben Casselman

articles.headline: At N.Y.U., Students Were Failing Organic Chemistry. Who Was to Blame?
articles.snippet: Maitland Jones Jr., a respected professor, defended his standards. But students started a petition, and the university dismissed him.
articles.abstract: Maitland Jones Jr., a respected professor, defended his standards. But students started a petition, and the university dismissed him.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the field of organic chemistry, Maitland Jones Jr. has a storied reputation. He taught the subject for decades, first at Princeton and then at New York University, and wrote an influential textbook. He received awards for his teaching, as well as recognition as one of N.Y.U.’s coolest professors.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Saul
